review:
I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

review:
[h1]Awful, Broken, Asset Flip FPS Game. But....[/h1]

I got this game for $.25 with a Badge Crafting Coupon.  Let me get the Pros and Cons out of the way:
[b]Cons:[/b]
[olist]
	[*] Bad graphics & outdated engine [Unreal 3]
	[*]Stupid simple AI
	[*]Very amateur level design. Maps are large, easy to get lost in, and boring to explore. They are positively littered with weapon & ammo pickups, enough that you will never die and never need to worry about running out of ammunition
	[*]Unskippable Cutscenes
	[*]Broken Controls
	[*]No in-game settings menu
	[*]No voice acting
[/olist]
[b]Pros:[/b]
[olist]
	[*]Destructable Environment
	[*]Meta-Progression System
	[*]Quick, Simple and Satisfying Gunplay reminiscent of CS:GO (Probably because it's the Unreal Engine stock gunplay but I digress...)
	[*]Achievements & Trading Cards
[/olist]
[b]Conclusion:[/b]
	You're probably only on this store page because you got a massive coupon for this game in exchange for crafting a badge. The developer was capable of including mechanics like Meta-Progression and Destructable Environments that are expected or even hard to find in quality, full-price titles. However...These mechanics are lost on a completely useless, base level, My-First-Asset-Flip FPS.
	
	I won't refund this and might catch myself playing it every now and again just to 1-hit brain-dead bots shaped like raptors. If you're a badge collector and have a coupon, don't hesitate to put a quarter in GabeN's Magic Money Machine as you may get ten minutes of fun and hundreds of Profile XP in exchange.

review:
Goofy dino aliens with equally silly ragdoll physics that cause them to collapse like the frame rate does half the time. The shots don't even go where your crosshair is. And once you get all the upgrades the survival mode becomes absolutely unhinged, surprisingly movement heavy too that it almost becomes...fun?

Eh, but what you pay for is what you get, game's as laughably short as it is a laughable hot mess, contender for hottest around, perhaps. The petrol station level tends to damn near softlock too, but I guess it's never crashed on me once? If you were "unlucky" enough to get a coupon for this game and are in need of a cheap laugh, go ahead and start kicking those alien dinos to death, they barely even tickle you for whatever reason. Parkour around the map and force them to go over obstacles, watch 'em pop upwards for no apparent reason. For a real challenge though, the upgrades become game breaking too fast, so yeah, don't expect to get much mileage out of this game.

Would've been a more favorable review if it were more self-aware of its outright outlandishness and had more content to it.....[i]oh wait, there's more? Ah, sure can't wait to lay my hands on those...sequels? Spin-offs? Hell if I know...[/i]

review:
The achievements all worked correctly - the 10,000 credits achievement must be exactly 10,000 though.  I was at 9700+ then played about 500 in story mode - my credits total did not change.  So I played and crept up to near 10,000 and played exactly the amount needed.  Each kill with a gun is 1 credit; each kill with a grenade is 5 credits.  Thus, the credits do not have to be reset as they used to be if you pass 10,000!!!

The 10,000 kills achievement is a grind unless you play on survivial mode - I only played about 200 kills on survival.  If you play mostly on survival, you can probably make 100% achievements in 8 or so hours.

The game is fairly fun with the starting guns, but leveling them up to gold level while leveling run speed, relard speed, and jump height makes it much more fun.  The gold tommy gun mows them down.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11208, 'playtime_forever': 198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1664798250}
review:
Action Alien is a rather poorly made story driven FPS where for whatever reason you're in a little town surrounded by spelling mistakes, terrible English translation, and most amusing of all, identical copies of a gas station and a motel.  Like exact same copies + pastes of the same asset.  Yep, this is an asset flip.  Not a scammy one as far as I can tell, but still a bunch of assets thrown in a blender and dumped out on Steam despite having no value as a video game.

It's clunky, unpolished, controls are locked, and the asset flipped AI monsters are laughably dumb. 

You don't have to take my word about how bad the game is, we can measure the interest in a game by how much people bothered to play it.  Action Alien has achievments, and they show us a very clear picture that the game absolutely failed to capture any interest from gamers.  The most commonly and easily attained achievement is for killing 100 aliens, pretty easy given the terrible AI and low TTK, but only around 8 percent of players bothered to get that far before uninstalling the game.  That's a tiny, tiny proportion of gamers who even bothered with this.  Ouch.

Action Alien has an overly optimistic price of around $5 USD, it's not worth it given the defects and shortcomings with the product, especially considering the sheer number of completely free, much higher quality games on Steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561198389640481', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 244, 'playtime_forever': 465, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 157, 'last_played': 1619562668}
review:
Honestly? I'm having tons of fun with this game! I really don't understand why it got so much negative feedback! What you get is exactly what you see in the trailer, so you can't say the dev has not been honest! But let's proceed gradually. This game is a wave-based arena shooter where you have to survive against few, but huge alien hordes. Aliens become progressively more numerous and dangerous, but you can unlock new weapons as you progress, so you become deadlier too. This is the basic idea. Now the details.

Here's what I liked:
- good variety of aliens, both melee and ranged
- a total of six bosses (bigger and stronger versions of regular aliens)
- the protagonist looks like Rambo (literally!)
- I only saw one map so far (the petrol station in the desert), but I liked it very much, it reminded me of Fallout New Vegas
- buildings are entirely destroyable, both by you AND by aliens; it's so cool to see bigger monsters strike down concrete walls to catch you!
- good variety of weapons: you can use a pistol, a revolver, a sub-machine gun, an assault rifle, a hunting rifle, a shotgun, a tommy gun, and even a grenade launcher!
- Rambo can be upgraded with perks; don't worry if you fail the first attempts: as you unlock perks, the game will become easier and easier; I suggest [spoiler] unlocking speed and health upgrades first [/spoiler]

- all weapons can be upgraded twice; yes, you read it correctly: TWICE! The second time they gain a beautiful golden skin and become true instruments of mass destruction! I can't even explain what monstrosity became my shotgun when it turned golden!
- the music is pleasant
- the pace is fast
- you can climb on the roofs of the buildings, and the enemies can actually follow you up there!
- aliens emit dog and cat cries
- death animations are fun

Here's what I didn't like:
- the reload system is annoying
- there are some annoying bugs: you can't pick up weapons if you approach them from the wrong angle, sometimes guns spawn inside a wall or just outside buildings (so you could think they didn't spawn entirely), and enemies often get stuck in rocks, walls or whatever
- boss fights aren't very fun or challenging
- waves automatically end even if a few enemies are still left; I think this is a means to prevent the player from getting stuck if the last enemies get bugged somewhere, but it is a bit disappointing nonetheless
- there's no stamina bar
- grenades often blow up right in your face
- you can get momentaneously stuck in rocks when you backpedal
- if you slightly touch smaller objects, they immediately fly away and emit a loud sound, so you can get scared for nothing
- you can only carry one pistol and one rifle at once; you have to drop them if you want other guns of the same class (one or two handed)

Finally, since I read some of the other players' reviews, I want to tell you what I find disappointing about their complaints:
- they complain because there are no saves between waves: well, this is absolutely normal for this kind of games, it's like complaining because Quake has no story or cutscenes!
- they say the music is annoying: as I already said, I found it pleasant and appropriate, I really don't understand this critic
- they say graphics are ugly: I actually liked them, they are colourful and almost cartoonish! And, by the way, who cares really? What I seek in a shooter is something called FUN!
- they say animations are ugly: this is true, I completely agree
- they say the weapon swapping system is annoying, because you have to press two buttons in sequence: I can assure you this is definitely NOT true! There is a small delay when you attempt to swap weapons, so you actually have the impression that one single pression wasn't enough, but if you want to select the rifle, you just have to press 1, while if you want to select the pistol, you just have to press 2

Overall: I absolutely recommend this game to all fans of wave-based arena shooters, I found it extremely fun and addictive! So, if you, like me, never want to miss the opportunity to smash some monsters with badass guns, this is what you want to play!
Cheers guys!

Edit: I have now tried all the maps. The wasteland and the tropical maps are very different from the petrol station: rather than survive against waves of aliens, you have to complete a series of tasks while being attacked by huge alien hordes. The locations are nice, but you have to run back and forth multiple times to complete your tasks, so overall these game modes are much more tedious than the wave-based mode.

review:
Having finished the game...

I can overlook certain things like the poor graphics, buggy environment (both the player character and the aliens get stuck in certain areas), the poor grammar, each intro scene lasted longer than needed and became painfully boring (and no way to skip them), and etc...

But make switching weapons difficult...while using weapon 1 and trying to switch to weapon 2 I had to hit "1" and then "2".  While using weapon 2 and trying to switch to weapon 1 I had to hit "2" and then "1".  That severely hurt the game.  What destroyed the game and made me NOT want to recommend it was this...

There are three maps.

In order to extend game play...each map requires you to run to one end of the map and back to one location, each time facing a wave of ever increasing difficulty aliens.  You don't do this just once, or twice...four or five times but SEVERAL times...

It wasn't done in either a good or fun way.

There is no way to save progress.  You had to finish everything at one time because if you left the game you had to restart it all over again.  If you died (for example, getting stuck in the environment and dying because you couldn't escape and get a heal) you had to start it all over again and that includes the intro scenes that should have been time edited by at least half...  It felt longer than needed.  It was painful.  It sucked the joy and fun out of the game...

It felt like a grind and THAT is unforgivable...

I cannot recommend this game...

author: {'steamid': '76561198188664927', 'num_games_owned': 1605, 'num_reviews': 386, 'playtime_forever': 644, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 644, 'last_played': 1561827078}
review:
https://youtu.be/Tq-JpdrGDtk
[h1] Game Summary: [/h1] 
This is basically just a mindless shooting game, with a few basic objectives tossed in to make it play somewhat differently from an arcade game where you attempt to get a high score.  Since you merely run back and forth doing short-distance fetch quests, with the set-up conveniently arranged, so the supplies are several yards away from the fuel-less but still operational vehicle.  The premise is paper thin and doesn't make sense, as these aliens attack you relentlessly for no theoretical reason.  You're a lone person in the middle of nowhere, with so little items on hand you don't even have food and water, let alone anything of potential danger to these aliens.  You'd think you were the POTUS based on how they mindlessly swarm at you in such abundant numbers.  


[h1] Pros: [/h1] 
	‚Ä¢ Although you likely won't play the game long enough for it to matter, you can unlock a variety of upgrades to make your character stronger and improve your firearms.  These RPG elements would honestly be welcome otherwise if the base game were better designed.  
	‚Ä¢ Some of the textures on different surfaces don't look great, but otherwise the graphics are acceptable.  
	‚Ä¢ There's a variety of guns available for you to use.  
	‚Ä¢ The game can be played with a controller.  
	

[h1] Cons: [/h1] 
	‚Ä¢ The opening cutscene can't be skipped.  It includes very poor English and doesn't inspire or interest me in playing the game.  Considering that it also contains a slight explanation on my objective, after I've seen it once, I already know that information, so why am I forced to sit through it each time?  This, on top of all the other flaws, made me give up on playing anymore.  I wasn't going to waste my time further.  
	‚Ä¢ The stage you play in is very constrained.  There are enough objects and items around, but it's not very large.  I don't feel like I'm in a wide-open area that I'm encouraged to explore and venture out into.  Instead, the objectives have me repeatedly go back and forth within a small area.  I don't know precisely where those items are, yet it's within a small hallway of acceptable territory I can play in.  
	‚Ä¢ I don't have any sense where enemies are spawning in from or when more will start coming in to attack me.  It's always surprising and disorienting when I see new aliens charging at me or off in the distance, especially when a new type suddenly shows up with several friends.  Considering my remote location and the unimportance of the area, it's especially confounding.  
	‚Ä¢ I'm not necessarily the best at locating items in-game, but it was very frustrating looking for the gasoline for my vehicle.  What annoyed me further is how after filling the fuel tank with one canister of gas, I couldn't move the vehicle over to pour the rest in.  That's what any logical person would do in those circumstances.  
	‚Ä¢ The odds are stacked against you.  Aliens run faster than you do, quickly gang up on you so you have to mow into them with your weapons, and later enemies have projectiles of their own.  Their range and accuracy seem to be quite high.  
	‚Ä¢ At random times, sparks would start going off around my character, and I could not figure out what was causing them to trigger.  Were they caused by a glitch as my character hit debris or something?  


[h1] Conclusion: [/h1] 
I enjoy a mindless shooter every once in a while, but this one quickly turned me off with its design choices.  I'd much rather have faced endless waves of enemies with powerful weapons and endless ammo, with no attempt at a story or objectives, than play this game.  Trying to navigate a limited stage that feels claustrophobic and constricting, while trying to run supplies back to the vehicle, only distracts me from dealing with the enemies.  Since the game doesn't properly build up the protagonist, situation, and stakes, I have little interest in doing them.  Were the game to make my character more capable of achieving them, perhaps I would, but it's quite cumbersome.  With various flaws dragging the experience down, I can't recommend this game, even for a time-wasting shooter.  It doesn't have the fun factor for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117837119', 'num_games_owned': 3902, 'num_reviews': 178, 'playtime_forever': 577, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 577, 'last_played': 1503377660}
review:
To be honest, I had a little bit of fun with this game in the first few gameplays, but after awhile, I realized that there wasn't much else to this game besides rack up a score and kill the same four or so aliens over and over again until your objective is completed.

There are three different campaigns, where the first two you need to escape the area through using a vehicle that requires gas, food, and water for you to progress. So, you are just going out to get those as you kill aliens along the way. There's also a survival mode, which is alright, but obviously gets repetitive.

The best thing that this game has is its gun upgrades. I've got to say, I really like the upgraded weapons because they all turn into explosive rounds for each of the weapons. They are a real step up from the base weapon, which is a nice touch.

To sum this game up, someone decided to copy and paste the same aliens over and over again for you to kill, leaving with little variety.

review:
So, I'm changing my rating of this game. Yes, I can totally be open-minded and have my opinion change if devs actively improve things...

...and this one did. The developer took this bucket of fetid stew and turned it into a playable game. Now, it's not going to win any awards for graphics, but it now qualifies as the mindless shooter that I was hoping for when I installed this thing in the first place.

The AI is predictable as heck, but again, I think that this is essentially a love letter to 90s FPS games, and in that regard it succeeds. The story mode can be kind of buggy (the next phase/wave of the level won't fire unless you've cleared 100% of the baddies, and sometimes some goofy little alien gets hung up on a rock or something waaaayyy far away from you and you'll spend 10 minutes looking for him to trigger the appropriate event), but I can attest that all three are completable. Honestly, the game is playable enough now that it would be fun to have a couple more environments to play with.

Survival mode only has two options for your location, and they're both pretty limited. But, it gets pretty fun once you've upgraded your hero and your weapons (it's fairly short-lived until you do that).

Hint: upgrade the revolver, hunting rifle, and tommy gun to full gold status as soon as you can. Then upgrade your ammo capacity and then health. After that, fill in whatever you want. Once you've done those first bits, you'll be able to survive most onslaughts with relative ease.

So here's to a developer that listened to the negative feedback and made his game better! Thank you for making it worth my time to run around blasting aliens...I hung in there long enough to 100% the achievements when previously I didn't think I'd ever even fire this game up again. But I saw the update posts from the dev and thought I'd give it a try, and now I'm glad that I did. Other devs out there in indie land: take this as a lesson. So long as you have the core of a decent game on your hands, you can turn around game reviews from objective people if you fix what's broken.

Changing my rating to a thumbs-up. Good job.

This looked like it might be a perfectly fun, mindless shooter, and I can be open-minded and appreciate something like that. Additional Tags: Delete Local Content & Remove from Library

TLDR: Too technically flawed to meet even a generously low entertainment value bar

A small and simple game about getting a getaway car in working order while being chased around a small desert map by zerglings/deathclaws. Game does a good job of telling you what you need to do, where to go, and gives you a chart for controls. The desert is simple but effective, kind of like a budget new vegas area. Waves become very numerous but if you die your score transfers over in credits to unlock perks and upgrade weapons for your future runs. Game also has a survival mode in case you managed to beat the getaway mission.

However the game is rather obnoxious to play, the monsters spawn constantly and without much rhyme or reason, you just constantly have to mow them down. The horde makes a footstep sound which gets multiplied severel dozen times over every second which is irrtating to the ears. Monsters will all try to beeline towards you but will clip into each other creating this strange glitchy infini-zergling monster in the process. Grenade damage does not seem to affect ennemies in its radius correctly. Monsters who path towards you will break down all kinds of structures in a chaotic manner sending structural parts furniture and just about everything in every direction with very low quality physics, often getting stuck in improbable spots like close to ceilings in the process. Not to mention that the constant running back and forth is not terribly inventive with it just being fairly linear little fetch quest missions.

[b]A Sorry Excuse for a Game[/b]

Action Alien will make you regret any time you spend playing it. Idle for the cards if you want to, that seems to be its main purpose on the Steam store but if you actually try to play this game, you won't have fun unless you like rubbing your eyes out with a cheese grater.

It starts out with you on an island after a plane crash then you're set an objective to get to the car. It becomes a tedious fetch quest grind after that and enemies increase in difficulty as you clear more objectives. Unfortunately, the Lazy AI, broken English, being easily overwhelmed by mobs, no shooting while running, lack of weapon switching (unless I missed it) and many other issues just make this a borefest.

Valve dropped its quality control standards many years ago and let slip thousands upon thousands of shovelware like this game. Many of which I recieved for free because well, you know, cards - that will be stopping soon I suspect.

I got this for free but wouldn't even recommend downloading it. It's just terrible.

review:
[h1]Basic Information[/h1]
[b]Title:[/b]  Action Alien
[b]Developer:[/b]  Devdan Games
[b]Publisher:[/b]  Devdan Games
[b]Genre:[/b]  First Person Shooter

[h1]General Impression[/h1]
I have to admit that there are few examples that come to mind, in which the environments take center stage within a video game. And yet Action Alien is just such a title. A development debut for the team which have published it on Steam, the first person shooter I had the chance to review today is not trying to stand out at all, but merely to project the developer‚Äôs vision into something palpable. I can respect that and I always try to encourage any idie dev at the start of his or her career.

By no means does my introduction imply, that I shall not judge the game through the same lenses I use for all my previous reviews. There are plenty of flaws in Action Alien and I fully intend to discuss them in detail. First of, I wish to present the more pleasant aspects which ultimate convinced me that this might still be a game worthy of being recommended. Though it features only three, medium-sized maps, there is plenty of room to maneuver, avoid or fall back from the foes that shall become increasingly more violent and aware of your presence, as you accomplish primary objectives. What is the mission in question? Survival and escaping from the alien menace. That is easier said than done since the will try to swarm you, wave after wave and there will be times, in which running from them and seeking ammo crates and simply resting and reloading your gun, shall prove to be just moments of respite.

The Wasteland map, presents a Route 66 alike scenario with a scenic approach towards the abandoned motels and gas stations that contain your necessary tools and weapons in order to survive the alien onslaught. ‚ÄúSurvive‚Äù is also the name of a spin-off map similar to the first one mentioned, but with increased difficulty and my favorite out of these 3, has to be ‚ÄúThe Tropical Hotel‚Äù. A mix of elements from both the lush jungle landscapes of Far Cry 1 and Dead Island‚Äôs beach bungalows (themselves copied from real-life island of Bali). You even have some temple ruins within that jungle terrain and my comparison to Far Cry 1 (released 13 years ago), is still an achievement for an indie dev. The cherry on top for these maps is that they also contain destructible structures.

I had to write about the maps and their static assets first, since the parts about the weaponry and the alien enemies, have not been to my liking at all. They both look as it the game‚Äôs still in an Alpha stage of development. Ugly textures and poor animations that really stand out in a negative way when compared to the landscapes and how nicely textured those are. So if you would like to purchase this title, at least know what you can expect from a visual perspective. The sounds themselves were more than decent as well as the general gameplay. It‚Äôs an indie FPS alright, that much is certain from the get-go. But it still manages to be fun through sheer diversity of weapons and enemy types, no matter how poorly rendered they are.

I don‚Äôt consider Action Alien overpriced but if you‚Äôre still uncertain, wait until you can pick it up during a Steam Sale or from a bundle and surely you won‚Äôt regret it then. I do hope the developer will attempt to provide some better textures to this game or at the very least, learn from his first project and pay more attention to details next time.

[h1]Strong Points[/h1]
+ Interesting environments.
+ Decent challenge for an affordable price.
+ Steam Achievements & Trading Cards.

[h1]Weak Points[/h1]
- Low-resolution and poorly textured, enemies and weapons.
- Repetitive gameplay.

[b]Rating 6/10[/b]

review:
While it's not a terrible game, I really can't think of any reason why I should recommend it. It's fun for a few minutes and then it just gets boring, repetitive and tedious. 

There are only a handful of different enemies in the game and they spawn in packs. There are some different colors per alien, but that's it. The AI is simple: run towards player (spit if possible) and that's it. You get a decent selection of weapons, you can carry one pistol and one big gun. But the aiming feels off, sometimes it's one bullet, one kill, other times I either miss or some of the enemies can soak up more bullets before dying. There's no indication of enemies being hit (until they die that is) and when they die the aliens just go ragdoll. You can shoot up some of the buildings, but you cannot shoot anything else (cacti for instance). The reloading animation of some weapons is rediciously slow as is the grenade throwing animation. Animations are also non interuptable, so you can't throw a grenade until the reloading animation is finished. Enemies will clip through walls and through each other. 

The first mission I played required me to bring five nearly empty gas canisters to a car in order to get away. Why not pour all the gasoline in one container? Would have saved me twenty minutes walking to and from the car. 

Some care went into designing the levels, while they look like something you'd expect to find in a late nineties FPS, the level design by itself isn't all bad. I also like the fact that you earn points by shooting aliens and you can use those points to buy upgrades for yourself (more health, stronger kick etc.) or upgrades for the weapons. As far as I could tell you earn 1 point per dead alien, most perks start at 100 points, so it'll be a while till you unlock everything. 

If only the game was more fun to play, this would be pretty cool. I know that ‚Ç¨5 isn't much, but there are older FPS games on Steam which cost as much and are a lot more fun to play. If you can get this game in a sale or in a bundle you'll probably have some fun with it, just don't expect too much.

review:
First impressions are obiviously not good. Graphics aren't very good and enemies turn to lumps of quivering jelly when they die. That's forgivable but there's the issue with reloading: it takes forever. And since the game will throw hordes of aliens at you no matter which mode you chose (Story or Survival), it can seem unplayable.

Nevertheless, I kept playing and discovered that even if you don't complete a map, you still earn credits for it. And these credits can be spent in the third area of the main menu: Perks. Among these perks is... wait for it... faster reload times. Also, there's a second page for upgrading weapons if you press Ok in that screen. So basically, the more you play, the more perks & upgraded weapons you will unlock and the easier this game will be.

It took me around nine hours to unlock everything and I'm still going to play the occasional map just to unlock those last two achievements. And even before then, I was feeling like an overpowered badass: reloading guns rapidly, carrying entire boatloads of ammo and grenades, and jumping over crates & onto buildings cause... why the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• not?

All in all, Action Alien (formely Alien Wasteland) is a fun little game that becomes easier as you play and unlock perks. And even if you die, you still earn credits for killing aliens. There is still the issues with destructible environments and important objects getting knocked around by rampaging lizards. Still, it's worth the price if you're looking for a fun little shooter to pass the time.

review:
Ever play 'Monster Hunt' in Unreal Tournament? It's a mod where... well, you hunt monsters. Tons of different levels created by players where you can team up - or solo - to kill a bunch of monsters. Action Alien reminds me of this, expect less polished. Ironic since you would think an independent game would be more polish than some random mod. Sadly, it's not.

If you pick up this game then prepare to get your hands dirty. It isn't perfect and it's rough around the edges. You need to be in the mindset where you know you're not playing an AAA title, or even a better game like Serious Sam. You may run into a few bugs like I did where a mission bugs out and places a gas canister a million miles away. I tried to go get it only to die since I was out of bounds. You'll then need to restart the mission and hope it doesn't happen again.

I rated this game thumbs up since I enjoyed it. I have no problem "downgrading" from top-of-the-line games to go back to a classic era. Nostalgia? Probably. If you're like me and enjoyed the Unreal Tournament mod, then I suggest picking this up and relive [i]a similar[/i] experience again.

Some faults I would like to point out that should have been fixed and/or added:

- [b]Not able to turn off sound and music[/b]
[i]I like to play games while steaming music. Hard to do that when you can't turn off the sound.[/i]
- [b]Monsters getting stuck behind rocks[/b]
[i]I was doing the 3rd mission and no more monsters were attacking me. I had to go near out of bounds to find a few monsters stuck behind some rocks. I was able to kill them, but this shouldn't happen.[/i]
- [b]Bugs[/b]
[i]In one mission my gas canister had spawned so far away that I couldn't complete that part of the task. When I restarted the mission they were all close to each other.[/i]

So finally i bought this to see what the fuss is all about. 

What is the game: A simple FPS Shooter in the desert (havent seen the other maps yet). It begins pretty easy but gets tough at the end. But you can add perks with credits and try again.
Though i am not a fan of the genre, i had pretty much fun shooting the different aliens. After some time there will be waves actively attacking you. And as far as i saw, every wave is different in story mode. 
Of course i wished there were more things to discover, it would add more variety. But the game focuses entirely on shooting and escaping from the desert.

So, it's as basic as it can get, but with all bugs eliminated after release (no single bug in 2 hours), and an open mind for little mindless games made by one person, and an anti nagging attitude, this one may be not the most creative, but still effective contribution to any games library.
